title: The overlooked problem with support itemization.
body:
A lot of people are complaining that {{item:3107}}  and {{item:3190}}  are overpowered or that because they are so good that they overshadow other support items like {{item:3504}}  {{item:3109}} or {{item:3050}} . 

What I think is an important aspect to this problem that everyone has been overlooking is that the issue doesn't lie with {{item:3107}}  and {{item:3190}}  but with {{item:3301}} /{{item:3303}} /{{item:3302}}  {{item:1001}} , and {{item:2049}} .

Lots of champions have item power spikes or good synergy with certain items. {{champion:122}}  gets a power spike when he completes {{item:3071}}  because of its synergy with his passive and the movespeed it gives him. On the other hand, {{champion:62}} also likes {{item:3071}}  but not as an in lane power spike but as a mid/late game item for teamfights since he can shred an entire enemy team with his ult.

And there is the problem. {{item:3107}}  and {{item:3190}} are teamfight items that someone would want in the mid to late game while {{item:3504}}  {{item:3109}} and {{item:3050}} are all items meant to help you and one other person or only your ADC. They would make pretty good power spike items in lane but supports don't HAVE power spike items because they have to use 800 gold on {{item:2049}}  850 gold on {{item:3098}}/{{item:3096}}/{{item:3097}}  and  900 or 1100 gold on tier two boots for a potential 2750 gold.  So by the time a support has bought all of those it is mid game and they want to buy items that help as many people as possible since teams will start grouping then.

The issue with {{item:3107}}  and {{item:3190}}  is not that they are OP or just too good to pass up, it's that they are teamfight items that can help out an entire team and by the time a support can start thinking about buying unique items it is mid game, when teamfights start happening, whereas the other support items either only help 1 or 2 people or are specialized in who they help (Most mages and tanks won't get much benefit from {{item:3504}} as an example). And since games usually don't get to late game right now, that one item or two items you get after sighstone, tier two boots, and tier two gold income item,  {{item:3107}}  and {{item:3190}} are usually the last fully completed support items you get.

So TLDR/ for everyone, the problem is that supports have to buy a bunch of particular items in the early game and by the time they do, mid game has rolled around and so their next purchases are teamfight oriented items that help as many people as possible.

Ardent Censer actually is used by a number of champions like Sona who can pass it onto more than one teammate pretty regularly. Not every support is geared to do that however, and I do think that's appropriate.

Knight's Vow fits better ironically on top lane tanks from what I've seen, but its stats are pretty low so it's not built that often for when you want to peel. Galio makes the item look really good. It does give sustain to tanks based on whoever s/he is bound to, so it's not a bad item in its nature, it's just not really that good of a **support** item.

Zeke's Herald honestly is confused. The item is bad because you can't control when you're able to use it, and it's nothing like Warlord's Bloodlust where something general like healing occurs. It's a powerful effect and the item's strength is based off of whether you get the effect or not. An idea a friend of mine had was that you'd gain charges by moving/being in combat with the person you're bound to, and at max charges the item would disable its ability to bind to champions but allow you to use the 100 stack effect by activating the item again. Would really make the item quite insane considering BoRK ADCs aren't that crit-heavy early on.

Mikael is just...outdated. The same issue I have with Chalice is the issue with Mikael's. MR on a support that you specifically have to dedicate to get an item just feels like a mid laner kind of thing since you're down there fighting with an AD champion. If Chalice didn't build off of a Null Mantle and just gave MP regen, its items would be in a much better state. Mikael already gives 10% more healing/shield power than Redemption, so it does have its niche.
Problem is people optimizing the items poorly. People keep rushing {{item:2049}} blindly (ironically) without taking in consideration the match up.

Well, what you said actually works as an argument for the claim that they're too powerful as well. Yes, they're bought because they're the best options for the teamfight-oriented midgame. And yes, you're locked out of the other options because by that point they aren't really options over these two items. 

So yes, Locket and Redemption are too strong for the point in the game where a support can actually start building items. They are overpowered compared to the other supportive items. This guy didn't say anything to the contrary of your point, and he didn't say they need to be nerfed. 
A buff/change to all the other options to make them viable options for mid game is in order, and that stems from the overwhelming advantage locket and redemption have over them in every single game. 

And so no, he didn't ignore what you said. He completely restated your conclusion in a way that retains the same meaning.

Them being overtunned would be debatable if there were other support items that had teamwide effects, but these two are the only ones with that kind of effect on multiple people. If everyone only bought one AD item or one armor item out of the myriad of choices in every game then you could say those items would be overpowered. Locket and Redemption though are the only team support items because all of the others effect only one person. 

His comment gave no reasoning for why he believed them to be OP, it didn't try to explain how someone would pick something like Zeke's over those other two items in the mid game, even if they were all balanced to the same level of power.

Maybe help me out, but couldn't it be argued that Ardent can be applied to multiple tem members, in the case of Sona or Soraka? Or if you build a locket then Ardent I think it applies to all you heal or shield.

Those are specific cases where a champion can buff all their allies and in the case of Soraka it's only on her ult, further, not everyone synergies with the buff it gives, most mages get absolutely nothing out of it and most tanks have such low attack speed that just 20-35% increased attack speed won't make them amazing damage dealers although it helps them more than mages.

There's a reason that the generic support abilities you see on almost all of them are heals and shields, because health is always going to be the stat that everyone shares in common (Unless Riot makes a champ that has mana for health or something) and so abilities that give health or faux health (shields) will always be the safest and most reliable choice for a class that has to be frugal with their money.

What you're describing is **exactly** what happened when Ravenous Hydra was first introduced. It was the only "team" auto attack item, and everyone and their mother bought it. 

He didn't need to give an explanation because your original post explained it pretty well. Although I'll still agree that his comment was completely pointless, it wasn't wrong. 

The fact they are the only team wide support items is the thing that makes them overpowered. It's not what they do that's too strong, it's what the other items _don't. _
